question: 1 Over the course of the passage, the primary focus shifts from
choice_A: A) Lymie’s inner thoughts to observations made by the other characters.
choice_B: B) an exchange between strangers to a satisfying personal relationship.
choice_C: C) the physical setting of the scene to the different characters’ personality traits.
choice_D: D) Lymie’s experience reading a book to descriptions of people in the restaurant.

question: 2 The main purpose of the first paragraph is to
choice_A: A) introduce the passage’s main character by showing his nightly habits.
choice_B: B) indicate the date the passage takes place by presenting period details.
choice_C: C) convey the passage’s setting by describing a place and an object.
choice_D: D) foreshadow an event that is described in detail later in the passage.

question: 3 It can reasonably be inferred that Irma, the waitress, thinks Lymie is “through eating” (line 37) because
choice_A: A) he has begun reading his book.
choice_B: B) his plate is empty.
choice_C: C) he is no longer holding his fork.
choice_D: D) he has asked her to clear the table.

question: 4 Lymie’s primary impression of the “party of four” (line 42) is that they
choice_A: A) are noisy and distracting.
choice_B: B) are a refreshing change from the other customers.
choice_C: C) resemble characters from his history book.
choice_D: D) represent glamour and youth.

question: 5 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_A: A) Lines 45-47 (“The women . . . down”)
choice_B: B) Lines 47-52 (“One . . . was”)
choice_C: C) Lines 55-59 (“But . . . them”)
choice_D: D) Line 69 (“Lymie . . . book”)

question: 1 The narrator indicates that Lymie finally closes the history book because
choice_A: A) his father has joined him at the table.
choice_B: B) the people at the other table are too disruptive.
choice_C: C) he has finished the chapter about the Congress.
choice_D: D) he is preparing to leave the restaurant.

question: 7 The primary impression created by the narrator’s description of Mr. Peters in lines 74-79 is that he is
choice_A: A) healthy and fit.
choice_B: B) angry and menacing.
choice_C: C) nervous and hesitant.
choice_D: D) aging and shriveled.

question: 8 The main idea of the last paragraph is that Mr. Peters
choice_A: A) neglects to spend any time with his family members.
choice_B: B) behaves as if he is a younger version of himself.
choice_C: C) is very conscious of symbols of wealth and power.
choice_D: D) is preoccupied with the knowledge that he is growing old.

question: 1 Which choice best supports the conclusion that Mr. Peters wants to attract attention?
choice_A: A) Lines 80-81 (“Apparently . . . change”)
choice_B: B) Lines 81-85 (“He straightened . . . hand”)
choice_C: C) Lines 90-91 (“The young . . . Mr. Peters”)
choice_D: D) Lines 91-93 (“He was . . . forty-five”)

question: 10 As used in line 93, “becoming” most nearly means
choice_A: A) emerging.
choice_B: B) fitting.
choice_C: C) developing.
choice_D: D) happening.

question: 1 In Passage 1, Beecher makes which point about the status of women relative to that of men?
choice_A: A) Women depend on men for their safety and security, but men are largely independent of women.
choice_B: B) Women are inferior to men, but women play a role as significant as that played by men.
choice_C: C) Women have fewer rights than men do, but women also have fewer responsibilities.
choice_D: D) Women are superior to men, but tradition requires women to obey men.

question: 12 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_A: A) Lines 6-10 (“But . . . all-pervading”)
choice_B: B) Lines 13-14 (“A man . . . debate”)
choice_C: C) Lines 16-18 (“he may coerce . . . sphere”)
choice_D: D) Lines 41-46 (“but whatever . . . sphere”)

question: 13 In Passage 1, Beecher implies that women’s effect on public life is largely
choice_A: A) overlooked, because few men are interested in women’s thoughts about politics.
choice_B: B) indirect, because women exert their influence within the home and family life.
choice_C: C) unnecessary, because men are able to govern society themselves.
choice_D: D) symbolic, because women tend to be more idealistic about politics than men are.

question: 14 As used in line 2, “station” most nearly means
choice_A: A) region.
choice_B: B) studio.
choice_C: C) district.
choice_D: D) rank.

question: 15 As used in line 12, “peculiar” most nearly means
choice_A: A) eccentric.
choice_B: B) surprising.
choice_C: C) distinctive.
choice_D: D) infrequent.

question: 16 What is Grimké’s central claim in Passage 2?
choice_A: A) The rights of individuals are not determined by race or gender.
choice_B: B) Men and women must learn to work together to improve society.
choice_C: C) Moral rights are the most important distinction between human beings and animals.
choice_D: D) Men and women should have equal opportunities to flourish.

question: 17 In Passage 2, Grimké makes which point about human rights?
choice_A: A) They are viewed differently in various cultures around the world.
choice_B: B) They retain their moral authority regardless of whether they are recognized by law.
choice_C: C) They are sometimes at odds with moral responsibilities.
choice_D: D) They have become more advanced and refined throughout history.

question: 18 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_A: A) Lines 58-61 (“Human . . . same rights”)
choice_B: B) Lines 61-65 (“These . . . imperishable”)
choice_C: C) Lines 71-76 (“To suppose . . . property”)
choice_D: D) Lines 77-81 (“When . . . nothingness”)

question: 1 Which choice best states the relationship between the two passages?
choice_A: A) Passage 2 illustrates the practical difficulties of a proposal made in Passage 1.
choice_B: B) Passage 2 takes issue with the primary argument of Passage 1.
choice_C: C) Passage 2 provides a historical context for the perspective offered in Passage 1.
choice_D: D) Passage 2 elaborates upon several ideas implied in Passage 1.

question: 20 Based on the passages, both authors would agree with which of the following claims?
choice_A: A) Women have moral duties and responsibilities.
choice_B: B) Men often work selflessly for political change.
choice_C: C) The ethical obligations of women are often undervalued.
choice_D: D) Political activism is as important for women as it is for men.

question: 21 Beecher would most likely have reacted to lines 65-68 (“Now . . . woman”) of Passage 2 with
choice_A: A) sympathy, because she feels that human beings owe each other a debt to work together in the world.
choice_B: B) agreement, because she feels that human responsibilities are a natural product of human rights.
choice_C: C) dismay, because she feels that women actually have a more difficult role to play in society than men do.
choice_D: D) disagreement, because she feels that the natures of men and women are fundamentally different.

question: 1 As used in line 14, “simple” most nearly means
choice_A: A) straightforward.
choice_B: B) modest.
choice_C: C) unadorned.
choice_D: D) easy.

question: 23 According to the passage, a significant attribute of conventional agriculture is its ability to
choice_A: A) produce a wide variety of fruits and vegetables.
choice_B: B) maximize the output of cultivated land.
choice_C: C) satisfy the dietary needs of the world’s population.
choice_D: D) lessen the necessity of nitrogen in plant growth.

question: Which choice best reflects the perspective of the “environmentalists” (line 27) on conventional agriculture?
choice_A: A) It produces inferior fruits and vegetables and is detrimental to the environment.
choice_B: B) It is energy efficient and reduces the need to convert wilderness to farmland.
choice_C: C) It is good for the environment only in the short run.
choice_D: D) It depletes critical resources but protects wildlife habitats.

question: 25 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_A: A) Lines 27-28 (“Of course . . . green”)
choice_B: B) Lines 28-31 (“They . . . corporations”)
choice_C: C) Lines 31-35 (“Environmentalists . . . sustainable”)
choice_D: D) Lines 42-45 (“More . . . think”)

question: Which statement best expresses a relationship between organic farming and conventional farming that is presented in the passage?
choice_A: A) Both are equally sustainable, but they differ dramatically in the amount of land they require to produce equivalent yields.
choice_B: B) Both rely on artificial chemicals for pest control, but organic farmers use the chemicals sparingly in conjunction with natural remedies.
choice_C: C) Both use nitrogen to encourage plant growth, but the nitrogen used in conventional farming comes from synthetic sources.
choice_D: D) Both create a substantial amount of nitrogen runoff, but only the type of nitrogen found in fertilizers used in conventional farming can be dangerous.

question: 27 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_A: A) Lines 13-14 (“Conventional . . . basis”)
choice_B: B) Lines 22-26 (“And since . . . environment”)
choice_C: C) Lines 51-53 (“They . . . widely”)
choice_D: D) Lines 61-65 (“Conventional . . . farming”)

question: 28 According to Foley, an “ideal global agriculture system” (line 80)
choice_A: A) focuses primarily on yield percentages and global markets.
choice_B: B) considers multiple factors in the selection of farming techniques.
choice_C: C) weighs the economic interests of farmers against the needs of consumers.
choice_D: D) puts the nutritional value of produce first and foremost.

question: 29 In line 88, “sheer” most nearly means
choice_A: A) transparent.
choice_B: B) abrupt.
choice_C: C) steep.
choice_D: D) pure.

question: 1 Which statement is best supported by the information provided in figure 1?
choice_A: A) The organic yield as a percentage of conventional yield is greater for vegetables than for fruits.
choice_B: B) The organic yield as a percentage of conventional yield is similar for cereals and all crops.
choice_C: C) The reported number of observations for each crop type exceeds 82.
choice_D: D) The organic yield as a percentage of conventional yield is greater for vegetable crops than it is for oilseed crops.

question: 31 Which of the following claims is supported by figure 2?
choice_A: A) Of the organically grown species represented, soybeans have the lowest yield.
choice_B: B) The organically grown maize and barley represented are comparable in their yields to conventionally grown maize and barley.
choice_C: C) Of the organically grown species represented, tomatoes have the highest yield.
choice_D: D) The organically grown species represented have lower yields than their conventionally grown counterparts do.

question: Over the course of the passage, the main focus shifts from a discussion of an experiment and its results to
choice_A: A) an explanation of the practical applications of the results.
choice_B: B) a consideration of the questions prompted by the results.
choice_C: C) an analysis of the defects undermining the results.
choice_D: D) a conversation with a scientist who disputes the results.

question: 33 The author of the passage suggests that crowds may be more effective at
choice_A: A) creating controversy than examining an issue in depth.
choice_B: B) reinforcing members’ ideas than challenging those ideas.
choice_C: C) arriving at accurate quantitative answers than producing valid qualitative judgments.
choice_D: D) ranking others’ opinions than developing genuinely original positions.

question: 1 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_A: A) Line 9 (“Sometimes . . . you”)
choice_B: B) Lines 11-14 (“Your . . . number”)
choice_C: C) Lines 17-20 (“According . . . value”)
choice_D: D) Lines 25-28 (“To test . . . opinions”)

question: 35 Which choice best supports the view of the “skeptics” (line 20)?
choice_A: A) Lines 55-58 (“Comments . . . reports”)
choice_B: B) Lines 58-60 (“And . . . them”)
choice_C: C) Lines 63-65 (“The ratings . . . them”)
choice_D: D) Lines 76-79 (“He . . . manipulated”)

question: 36 Which action would best address a question Watts raises about the study?
choice_A: A) Providing fewer fake positive comments
choice_B: B) Using multiple websites to collect ratings
choice_C: C) Requiring users to register on the website before voting
choice_D: D) Informing users that voting data are being analyzed

question: 37 As used in line 85, “boost” most nearly means
choice_A: A) increase.
choice_B: B) accelerate.
choice_C: C) promote.
choice_D: D) protect.

question: 1 As used in line 86, “scale” most nearly means
choice_A: A) level.
choice_B: B) wage.
choice_C: C) interval.
choice_D: D) scheme.

question: 39 In the figure, which category of news has an artificially up-voted mean score of 2.5?
choice_A: A) Business
choice_B: B) Politics
choice_C: C) Fun
choice_D: D) General news

question: showed the smallest difference in mean score between artificially up-voted comments and control comments?
choice_A: A) Culture and society
choice_B: B) Information technology

choice_D: D) General news

question: 41 Data presented in the figure most directly support which idea from the passage?
choice_A: A) The mean score of artificially down-voted comments is similar to that of the control.
choice_B: B) The patterns observed in the experiment suggest that people are suspicious of negative social influence.
choice_C: C) The positive bias observed in users of the news site may not apply to human behavior in other contexts.
choice_D: D) The type of story being commented on has an impact on the degree to which people can be influenced.

question: 1 According to the passage, Maguire’s findings regarding taxi drivers are significant because they
choice_A: A) demonstrate the validity of a new method.
choice_B: B) provide evidence for a popular viewpoint.
choice_C: C) call into question an earlier consensus.
choice_D: D) challenge the authenticity of previous data.

choice_A: A) initial.

choice_C: C) necessary.
choice_D: D) fundamental.

question: 1 As used in line 39, “matched” most nearly means
choice_A: A) comparable.
choice_B: B) identical.
choice_C: C) distinguishable.
choice_D: D) competing.

question: 48 The main purpose of the fifth paragraph (lines 57-65) is to
choice_A: A) relate Maguire’s study of mental athletes to her study of taxi drivers.
choice_B: B) speculate on the reason for Maguire’s unexpected results.
choice_C: C) identify an important finding of Maguire’s study of mental athletes.
choice_D: D) transition from a summary of Maguire’s findings to a description of her methods.

question: According to the passage, when compared to mental athletes, the individuals in the control group in Maguire’s second study
choice_A: A) showed less brain activity overall.
choice_B: B) demonstrated a wider range of cognitive ability.
choice_C: C) exhibited different patterns of brain activity.
choice_D: D) displayed noticeably smaller hippocampal regions.

question: 50 The passage most strongly suggests that mental athletes are successful at memorization because they
choice_A: A) exploit parts of the brain not normally used in routine memorization.
choice_B: B) convert information they are trying to memorize into abstract symbols.
choice_C: C) organize information into numerical lists prior to memorization.
choice_D: D) exercise their brains regularly through puzzles and other mental challenges.

question: 1 Which choice provides the best evidence for the answer to the previous question?
choice_A: A) Lines 66-72 (“Surprisingly . . . way-finding”)
choice_B: B) Lines 72-73 (“At first . . . sense”)
choice_C: C) Lines 79-81 (“Maguire . . . memorized”)
choice_D: D) Lines 85-87 (“They . . . childhood”)

question: 1 52 The questions in lines 74-78 primarily serve to
choice_A: A) raise doubts about the reliability of the conclusions reached by Maguire.
choice_B: B) emphasize and elaborate on an initially puzzling result of Maguire’s study of mental athletes.
choice_C: C) imply that Maguire’s findings undermine earlier studies of the same phenomenon.
choice_D: D) introduce and explain a connection between Maguire’s two studies and her earlier work.
